metadata.case_name: Owners of lands in Virk Kalan, Sewana and Mehnd v. State of Punjab and others
metadata.case_number: Civil Appeal Nos. 743 of 1963, 553 and 554 of 1962

facts.text: Appellants in Civil Appeal No. 743 of 1963 are owners of lands in village Virk Kalan, Tehsil and District Bhatinda.
Appellants in Civil Appeals Nos. 553 and 554 of 1962 are owners of lands in villages Sewana and Mehnd of Tehsil Hansi in District Hissar.

Proceedings for consolidation of holdings ongoing in these villages under East Punjab Holdings (Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation) Act, 1948 (Act 50 of 1948), as amended by East Punjab Holdings (Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation) (2nd Amendment Validation) Act, 27 of 1960.

In village Virk Kalan, 270 kanals and 13 marlas of shamlat deh land given to village Panchayat for management and realisation of income (ownership still shown as Shamlat Deh in proprietors' names); 10 kanals and 3 marlas reserved for abadi to be distributed among entitled persons; 3 kanals and 7 marlas reserved for manure pits.

In village Sewana, 400 kanals and 4 marlas set apart for village Panchayat for extension of abadi and grants of 8 marlas to each family of non-proprietors; 16 kanals reserved for primary school; some more for phirni.
In village Mehnd, land reserved for village Panchayat, school, tanning ground, hospital, cremation ground and non-proprietors.
No compensation paid to proprietors for the lands reserved and allotted.

Appellants filed Civil Writ Petition No. 319 of 1961 contending distribution of shamlat lands illegal and could only be among proprietors, not non-proprietors; dismissed by Grover J. on authority of Jagat Singh v. Punjab State; special leave granted by Supreme Court.
Writ Petition No. 761 of 1957 (leading to C.A. 553/1962) dismissed by Grover J.; Letters Patent Appeal filed.
Writ Petition No. 454 of 1958 (leading to C.A. 554/1962) heard by Bench with Letters Patent Appeal and both dismissed on August 18, 1960; no certificate for appeal but special leave obtained.
On March 3, 1956, Punjab Government added Rule 16(i) to Consolidation Rules for reservation of abadi for proprietors and non-proprietors.
On April 9, 1957, Punjab Government added Rule 16(ii) for reservation of lands for Gram Panchayat out of common pool.
Rule 16(ii) declared ultra vires by Punjab High Court on November 5, 1959 in Munsha Singh v. State of Punjab.

Appeals heard and closed for judgment on April 27, 1964; postponed due to vacation; reassembled July 20, 1964; Constitution (Seventeenth Amendment) Act, 1964 assented June 20, 1964; counsel declined to argue on new Art. 31A.

legal_issues.text: Whether the transfer of shamlat deh owned by proprietors to village Panchayat for management without compensation and conferment of proprietary rights on non-proprietors in abadi deh is illegal and ultra vires Art. 31, or protected by Art. 31A.
Whether East Punjab Holdings (Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation) (2nd Amendment Validation) Act, 27 of 1960 breaches Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31.
Whether Rules 16(i) and 16(ii) are ultra vires.
Whether Punjab Village Common Lands (Regulation) Act, 1954 is valid.

petitioner_arguments.text: Distribution of shamlat lands illegal; if redistributed, only among proprietors, not to non-proprietors.
Amending Act 27 of 1960 in breach of Arts. 19(1)(f) and 31; Rules 16(i) and (ii) ultra vires; Common Lands Regulation Act part of scheme and invalid.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Arts. 19(1)(f), 31; K.K. Kochuni v. State of Madras

petitioner_arguments.text: Covered by Kochuni case as not agrarian reform but bare transfer of rights.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: K.K. Kochuni v. State of Madras

respondent_arguments.text: Act 27 of 1960 gives retrospective validity to Rules 16(i) and (ii); protected by Art. 31A; Kochuni not applicable.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Art. 31A; Jagat Singh v. Punjab State

court_reasoning.text: Reviews legislative history: Consolidation Act s.18,46; Rule 16(i),(ii); Amendment Act 27/1960 adding s.2(bb) 'common purpose', s.23A vesting management in Panchayat/State; Panchayat Act s.19 duties; Common Lands Act ss.3,4,6,7 no compensation; Security of Land Tenures Act.
court_reasoning.key_observation: These form general scheme of agrarian reforms including rural planning, consolidation, utilisation of waste lands.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Kochuni as special case of bare transfer without agrarian reform; other precedents give wide meaning to Art. 31A covering consolidation, ceilings, redistribution, rural planning.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consolidation is agrarian reform; assignment to Panchayat for common purposes (schools, pits etc.) essential to rural economy, self-sufficiency.

court_reasoning.text: Abadi deh for artisans part of rural planning; Panchayat authority under Part III; protected even if acquisition.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Four Acts part of larger reforms; modifications protected by Art. 31A.

holdings.text: Impugned provisions within protection of Art. 31A as part of agrarian reforms and rural planning.
Act 27/1960, Rules 16(i),(ii), Common Lands Regulation Act valid; High Court correct in Jagat Singh case.

precedents_cited.case_name: Munsha Singh v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Declared Rule 16(ii) ultra vires, led to Amendment Act 27/1960.
Held Act 27/1960 saved by Art. 31A; Kochuni not applicable.

precedents_cited.case_name: K.K. Kochuni v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 31A for agrarian reform only; not bare transfer; narrow view.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hukam Singh v. State of Punjab
Atma Ram v. State of Punjab
precedents_cited.relevance: Wide amplitude to Art. 31A for agrarian reforms like land ceilings, tenant purchase.

precedents_cited.case_name: Thakur Raghubir Singh v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Confined to facts; wide meaning to estate/rights.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gangadhar Narayanrao Majumdar v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Right of inamdar as right in estate protected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Ram Narain Medhi v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: Land distribution to prevent concentration protected.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sonapur Tea Co. Ltd. v. Must. Mazirunnessa
precedents_cited.relevance: Ceiling rights as rights in estate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Burrakur Coal Co. Ltd. v. Union of India
State of Bihar v. Rameshwar Pratap Narain Singh
State of Bihar v. Umesh Jha
precedents_cited.relevance: Ancillary provisions protected if part of reform Act.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Holdings (Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation) Act, 1948 (Act 50 of 1948)
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers for reservation of land for common purposes; vesting management in Panchayat; retrospective amendments.

statutes_cited.name: East Punjab Holdings (Consolidation and Prevention of Fragmentation) (2nd Amendment Validation) Act, 27 of 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Validates Rule 16(ii); adds definitions and s.23A retrospectively.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Gram Panchayat Act, 1953 (Act 4 of 1953)
statutes_cited.relevance: Duties of Panchayat for rural administration, welfare.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Village Common Lands (Regulation) Act, 1954 (Act 1 of 1954)
statutes_cited.relevance: Vesting shamlat deh in Panchayat; utilisation for village benefit; no compensation.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Security of Land Tenures Act, 1953 (Act 10 of 1953) as amended
statutes_cited.relevance: Security of tenure, tenant purchase, ceilings; part of agrarian reforms.

outcome.summary: The appeals challenging the reservation and allotment of shamlat deh lands to village Panchayat and non-proprietors without compensation under consolidation proceedings, and validity of related Acts and Rules, are dismissed. The provisions are held protected by Art. 31A as part of agrarian reforms and rural planning.

key_quotes.text: "Consolidation of holdings is really nothing more than a proper planning of rural areas and this planning must of necessity take notice of vacant and waste lands."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains consolidation as rural planning under agrarian reform.

key_quotes.text: "If agrarian reforms are to succeed, mere distribution of land to the landless is not enough. There must be a proper planning of rural economy and conditions."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies Panchayat assignments as essential to reforms.

key_quotes.text: "India lives in villages and a scheme to make villages self-sufficient cannot but be regarded as part of the larger reforms."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Broadens Art. 31A to include village self-sufficiency.
